Apr 12

Sketch 43: A brief tour of fact vs¬†folklore

Spoilers: No, you don‚Äôt need to learn git, and design ‚â†¬†code

Sketch‚Äôs 43 will change some fundamental aspects of how software breathes life into design ideas. It‚Äôs going to be fun to watch new tools, plugins and workflows take shape. However, some folklore has emerged, like designers can now produce front-end code directly, Sketch source files are de facto version controlled repositories, and that designers need to know git.

A recently published article summarizes itself with six claims which I‚Äôll visit one by one.

1. Sketch 43 now has an editable file format (the BIG news)

True! Sketch 43 produces a mix of binary and JSON files to describe the pages, artboards and objects therein. Is that big news? Well, in their own Medium post about it, Bohemian BV, the Netherlands based makers of Sketch, had this to say.

‚ÄúWith this release, we‚Äôve introduced a new Sketch file format, which means documents created with Sketch 43 will not be compatible with previous versions.‚Äù

And that‚Äôs it. You could nearly fit that in one tweet. That does feel too humble, though. An open file format sets the stage for much more robust plugin development as well as a new generation of tools that could potentially produce some usable code from Sketch source (and vice versa). That is significant indeed, and there are some informed and detailed discussions about it that I encourage the curious among us to visit.

2. Sketch 43 levels the playing [field] for a mutual understanding between designers and engineers

False. It creates the about same amount of mutual understanding we currently see between illustrators and engineers both looking at SVG source (also text files). The fact that Sketch‚Äôs file format is open doesn‚Äôt therefore mean designers and engineers will merge concepts and vocabularies as a result. Any shared field of understanding in a post Sketch 43 world will be about as it was before.

But we should play it out anyway. Imagine one scenario where a designer changes some symbol properties in Sketch, and a tool notices and understands that change, producing code that updates, say, a CSS build or a React component, then builds and pushes that change to some dev or staging environment. A designer invokes a tool and code comes out like magic. That doesn‚Äôt feel like genuine understanding. In fact, I‚Äôd argue that it makes them more abstract and removed from one another.

Another scenario might have designers rolling code in order to change a design, and pushing commits to an actual repo. Not likely. More on that in a bit.

Still another could have developers editing Sketch source directly to change some aspect of the design, and checking that code in so the Sketch app can render those changes next time the designer works with it. The article even offers an example of this for us:

‚ÄúThe engineer, who knows that marketing needs a couple more buttons [on a nav bar created by the designer], can add those to all screens in your¬†.sketch file herself.‚Äù

Leaving aside the issue of engineering acting on some kind of backchannel information from marketing, this might look something like‚Ä¶

$ git commit -m "Add buttons to nav bar" -m "BTW John in Marketing OK'd it. Thought I would update your Sketch design."

To which the designer might say‚Ä¶

So now that someone updated the Sketch source, it could theoretically serve as the first mover that builds some important front end code.

But is that a good idea? And how was the engineer in this scenario even able to slip in a design change? Because of this claim‚Ä¶

3. Bohemian Coding creates a new design workflow and standard, the design repo (similar to the development repo)

Theoretically true, but empirically false. There‚Äôs a fair bit to unpack here.

First, a clarification. The article describes a code repository as ‚Äúthe application that runs the software UI.‚Äù I don‚Äôt know what is meant by that, but I‚Äôll offer this more concrete definition in its place: A code repository is a collection of project files (typically source code for an app or service) that also stores their revision history (version control).

Distributed version control, in simple terms, allows several people to work on a copy of a project‚Äôs source code independently of one another and manage changes to those files without everything getting screwed up and conflicted.

Now, here‚Äôs the root of a simple React project, versioned with git.

Here‚Äôs what a Sketch 43 file looks like under the hood (after you unzip it).

It all kind of looks the same maybe. Each have some JSON files and some folders. That is the sole basis for the claim that Sketch creates design repos and new standards.

A new ‚Äúdesign workflow and standard‚Äù should makes things easier and more accessible for everyone at each point in the cycle. This wouldn‚Äôt do that, because‚Ä¶

4. Designers have to learn Git (version control). Yup.

No. False. If you wanted to release a product or feature and literally promise its failure, then have it diss your user‚Äôs habits, preferences, and workflows while at the same time introducing new pain points.

Designers aren‚Äôt going to start doing‚Ä¶

$ git checkout design-tweaks

And after an hour of design work‚Ä¶

$ git add .
$ git commit -m ‚ÄúChange global button radius to 4px. Darken primary color by 15%‚Äù -m "Also add trendy gradient background on main headlines."
$ git push origin design-tweaks
To https://github.com/hipsterdesigner/hipdesign.git
 ! [rejected]  design-tweaks -> design-tweaks (non-fast-forward)
error: failed to push some refs to 'https://github.com/hipsterdesigner/hipdesign.git'

Wait what? Who else is in here?

$ git pull --rebase origin design-tweaks
From github.com:hipsterdesigner/hipdesign.git
 * branch  design-tweaks -> FETCH_HEAD
First, rewinding head to replay your work on top of it...
Fast-forwarded design-tweaks to 129a6981e721adc5415b7c2751c0d9ba2d189d6b.
$ git log
commit 129a6981e721adc5415b7c2751c0d9ba2d189d6b
Author: That engineer from earlier<anengineer@somesstartup.com>
Date:   Tue Apr 09 10:32:44 2017 -0400
   Add buttons to nav bar.
   BTW John in Marketing OK'd it. Thought I would update your Sketch design.

üòí

$ git push origin design-tweaks
Counting objects: 34, done.
Delta compression using up to 8 threads.
Compressing objects: 100% (34/34), done.
Writing objects: 100% (34/34), 688 bytes | 0 bytes/s, done.
Total 34 (delta 0), reused 0 (delta 0)
To git@github.com:hipsterdesigner/hipdesign.git
   129a698..bcb0130  design-tweaks -> design-tweaks

This straw man example doesn‚Äôt prove workflows can‚Äôt change and improve. But when they do, it won‚Äôt be from designers having to learn git. It‚Äôll be from Sketch‚Äôs open format leading to more powerful plugins and third party tools to make the day to day collaboration of designers and developers faster while not upending their existing habits. Folks like Gitlab and Anima are already at it.

Speaking of making things easier for designers and developers‚Ä¶

5. Teams can go straight from design into code without mundane frontend development

False. This is pretty much the central idea being trafficked. I‚Äôm going to take this one to mean that a designer creates or updates an object in Sketch, and this object manifests itself as deployable code without the mind and hand of a front-end engineer involved.

The article says it this way:

‚ÄúDesigners can now generate any layout composition in a matter of minutes and clicks. Translating a visual design to CSS/HTML is now a mundane task of the past. The responsibility for all-things-UI is back in the hands of designers.‚Äù

Sketch 43 could make possible some interesting platforms. Maybe one that generates Bootstrap or Foundationesqe styles and libraries directly from a designer‚Äôs hand‚Äî sort of a next gen WISIWYG in some ways. But to classify front end development as an unvarying, tiresome monolith that teams can skip is hyperbolic at minimum.

6. Design IS Code, Code IS Design

There‚Äôs truth to that in a metaphorical sense. But Sketch is a tool to express the output of design thought. Code and design are different things that inhabit different zones of effort. Sketch 43 will further remove some pain and inefficiencies of product development cycle, but it won‚Äôt necessarily merge those zones.

As we all witness a world shifting towards automation generally, distinctions about what that actually means in context are important, I think. Here, design is still design, and that‚Äôs ok.
